etymology.description: 金(金) (jīn, "metal") + 旁(旁) (páng) (phonetic) = metal object denoting weight -> pound
etymology.interpretation: 鎊(鎊) (bàng, "pound") combines 金(金) (jīn, "metal") signifying currency and objects of metal with 旁(旁) (páng) for phonetic approximation, representing the British currency 'pound', originally associated with a specific weight of precious metals.
etymology.simplification: 金(金) (jīn, "metal") was replaced with 钅(钅) (jīn, "metal") to form the simplified character 镑(鎊).

examples.chinese: 我买了一鎊苹果(我買了一鎊蘋果)。
examples.english: I bought one pound of apples.

examples.chinese: 厨师投掷一鎊的肉(廚師投擲一鎊的肉)，以展示力量(以展示力量)。
examples.pinyin: Chúshī tóuzhì yī bàng de ròu, yǐ zhǎnshì lìliàng.
examples.english: The chef tossed a pound of meat to display his strength.

examples.chinese: 他用力举起一鎊铁锤(他用力舉起一鎊鐵錘)。
examples.pinyin: Tā yònglì jǔ qǐ yī bàng tiěchuí.
examples.english: He lifted a one-pound iron hammer with force.
